What happens on the battlefield is rarely the thing that decides a war. Normally, the preparations beforehand determine what happens when the fighting begins‚Äîand these preparations are what settle the outcome of the war itself. 

This truth is playing out along the roads and in the towns of Kharkiv Oblast, the province that includes Ukraine‚Äôs second-largest city. The stunningly swift advance of Ukrainian forces, which started around September 1 and sped up soon after, has easily been the most dramatic‚Äîand for Ukraine and its supporters, the most uplifting‚Äîepisode of the war since the current Russian invasion began on February 24. 

In a few days the Ukrainians liberated about as much territory as Russia had captured in a few months, while causing the disintegration of Russian forces around Izium, Kupyansk, and other logistically vital cities. 
From the outside, Ukraine appears to have changed the whole complexion of the war.
In other words Putin can't spare any forces to dictate terms this time around. That happens when you get bogged down in a special operation.
